CD141141A62F4FFC8C4346C0076F70E2.description: Design artworks using the decorative styles of the Middle Ages

B0E43849F6844204B5AA0DEF703C7B1C.description: View artworks and architecture from the Middle Ages as an inspiration for talking about and creating art

4C84D8D75474421FBA96B284F7D318BC.description: Discuss examples of knowledge that First Nations, Métis, and Inuit can share through artworks.

2CEFAD4E3207491CAB0B7C800139BB1C.description: Create visual art that reflects the history or traditions of Alberta.

57E52583B2D140F194CFB0510F900E8A.description: Explore the significance of local artworks

8431D8B903834934B9708BCE4C9E6F61.description: Investigate information shared through petroglyphs found in Alberta

1A171E8F56F94660A029780D99E922FE.description: Demonstrate how artistic roles and responsibilities contribute to a sense of community.

4C7037B4B34B421A964050B44E2C288C.description: Participate in visual arts as a member of an artistic community

18D3AF1E76954D848EDA9386EE9317B6.description: Culture was revealed through the artworks of the Middle Ages.

D2EBDF6C31804C3CA66ACFABB30F8073.description: Visual arts in Alberta can reflect the culture of those who came before us and those who live here now

B5C04D9AE6E04317B48820D8812F433E.description: The culture of an artistic community is about shared ways of being together and reaching common goals.

E86172EDA9AF4E74AFCE04489F44680C.description: When communities unite through the arts, culture can be learned.

49402231E41E4AF29AC05F9DA27160A8.description: A hypostyle mosque is an architectural design where the roof rested upon pillars or columns

12DB613FEF624B87A880FD0203B5A9F8.description: A mosque is a central gathering place required for common prayer and community gatherings.

628C899A6F9845F688C96F01202C330F.description: Medieval Islamic architecture can be seen in Alhambra Palace, 1238-1358, in Granada, Spain The Great Mosque of Cordoba, 784-1146 CE

4AA05824DCB2410CB7A1845FD04B2293.description: Silk weaving led to the art form of carpets in Islamic art, which included elaborate patterns and bright colours.

E2BB237F0A0948D8A00891883D9AC5D1.description: Islamic books or manuscripts were illustrated in a style called illumination, which often featured complex patterns and designs using geometric, botanical, and animal forms

5A30FB91F8CE415F8813F4AF4449B84B.description: Decorative designs on ceramics and folk pottery included inscriptions and proverbs animals, usually birds from the folkloric past geometric designs abstract patterns

B21FB098467E46A99816258535B09117.description: Islamic artworks used decorative forms of art, including calligraphy folk pottery rugs and carpets

E5347BD63868478E8BBCACB177F492FD.description: Artworks in medieval Islam discouraged the use of shapes and detailed patterns to depict the human form

3DD0897862CE485C80A7CFCAF6A54FAF.description: Traditional Gothic cathedrals can be viewed today, as seen in Notre-Dame in Paris, France Our Lady of Chartres in Chartres, France

DBD9B503D0EE426688C9FF89867567C7.description: Gothic cathedrals were built with specific and important architectural styles, including spires pointed arches flying buttresses rose windows stained glass and statues

A9933B3FA6564BD09AED5F4C282A71FB.description: Architectural styles from the Middle Ages still exist today, some of which can be seen in Carolingian Palatine Chapel, Gothic: Westminster Abbey, Old-New Synagogue of Prague, and Hotel-Dieu, Ostrogothic: Basilica of San Vitale Romanesque or Norman: Abbaye de Cluny, Durham Cathedral, and Carcassonne

E526D83D3B2D452B9EEB7A69146910A2.description: Architecture in the Middle Ages was often built with consideration for protecting the people inside the buildings, including castles on rocky hilltops and homes surrounded by walls.

0D9244A2CF694501ACC07ABF3D400426.description: Tapestries, including The Unicorn Tapestries, were woven artworks that could communicate information about history legends religious teachings everyday life

A66529BFFB6F462CB25AD45150564C88.description: The Book of Kells is a medieval manuscript in which decorations, including images and borders, accompany the text

1A2842F3221C4162BA82DD63CA782203.description: Medieval European artworks were often based on people and events from religious stories and classical myths, including heroes, heroines, and gods that are still commonly referenced in English literature, in brand names, and in everyday writing and conversation people and events narrated in Jewish and Christian stories

AF54A04D69D74423A339C847058BD910.description: Lawren Harris (1885-1970) was a member of an influential group of Canadian artists called the Group of Seven that captured the Alberta landscape in oil paintings.

A03DCA4D5EF846319E941FBE4AE8BE34.description: The Métis people of Alberta are renowned for their floral beadwork.

52A36363283B42F0A706D10DC559BA3C.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit share knowledge through artworks that can include stone, wood, and bone carvings pottery embroidery porcupine quillwork birchbark art geometric patterns and motifs on hide beading weaving paintings

B5E5373D999E4BF39699C0510F710641.description: Writing-on-Stone Provincial Park in Alberta has many examples of First Nations petroglyphs

8AAA8DEDC4AA4343AF236B44CD504F3F.description: Petroglyphs are a form of written text that some societies have interpreted as visual art.

1625BF489D364370A00D14843B038510.description: Visual artwork in Alberta has been influenced by the histories and traditions of artists from a variety of cultures

793B787C559E443C989D5878BA44DB82.description: The culture of an artistic community can support the caring and respectful inclusion of all participants

C3B42C477FFA4715961CB0FD4E96DA56.description: Culture can be enhanced when artistic communities participate, communicate, are engaged, and share responsibilities.

101332D0A5BB41EAAC88A3E83EB55DCE.description: Students relate how culture is reflected in visual arts across time and place

5D3A196023204D91A941D56FDDB12BE4.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

FD1FDEAD9DB54E79BB7AE97E7EACCBA3.description: Experiment with how displaying an artwork can influence how it is viewed.

6EF6CA43FA704B7F9476008A6EFDC61B.description: Accompany artworks with titles and descriptions of a narrative

8DF3D5F8F8D842CBADF069C2B39E607D.description: Make experimental and informed artistic choices when creating artworks

76426D7AB91C4DB48E41B469352BD284.description: Investigate how the elements of art can be used to represent perspective in artworks.

81374ABE51594F948B39FEA3D58FF62B.description: Explore how the elements of art can be used to communicate mood or feelings.

04434C66A2B646968AA8544F1835AE25.description: Explore how principles of design can enhance communication of a narrative

A5C461CAE04847E29BB2416ECE911F0B.description: Create two- and three-dimensional works of art to convey a narrative

1CBA7BB787D64E479A4880B89F9E40C4.description: Choose an inspiration for representing a narrative

903CAC36251849408C7ABAE08BB42C33.description: A viewer's reaction to an artwork can be in response to how the artwork is presented or created.

1BBB9AC6DD0C4B3BBB24A00181888277.description: A narrative in visual arts can be shaped by the artist, curator, or viewer

5A37AC5ADDFA464B9EE559A17A3A79AF.description: Feelings and mood can be interpreted visually through the use of line, shape, and colour

81549B522E1C467CB3FE2CF2D9B7F20E.description: A narrative can communicate points of view or perspectives of an individual or a group

7F5C84D85BE14335A5021C34DA7F91B5.description: A narrative can be factual or fictitious.

A51E6425507742D3AC4FECCD5CFF8F9E.description: A narrative in artworks can be illustrated as a partial or whole representation.

1877D817CB4C4F82B4CB2E027B4F18DE.description: A narrative told through visual arts can be combined with other art forms, including dance, drama, and music.

2D8C9FA3B7E44F6C960055EDE58DF56B.description: Additional information about a narrative can be communicated through titles and descriptions about the artwork

928D0065E536471986E66D5538049315.description: A curator chooses how artworks are displayed, which can shape the way a narrative is presented

79771884DEEF4FB9BC9E9706B504427A.description: An artist can shape a narrative through the use of elements of art creative processes media tools, techniques, and methods experimentation or informed artistic choices

20840F255BF7417F9D776BDDC9A7B1CC.description: Principles of design, including harmony and contrast, can influence how well the elements of art work together to communicate a narrative.

F8E44A2560D44A58A8AEFB2B403D5F8B.description: Texture can create mood or evoke an emotional response when incorporated into artworks

51160A88EAF346319FC4DE80DE25CF64.description: Warm and cool colours can represent feelings in a narrative

AB8DACA4F46042679D710A73004F7C4F.description: Points of view or perspectives can reflect ideas, experiences, and culture.

B34A3B8307D942E3AE3A35C4FAB38C9C.description: Group expression in visual arts can be seen in murals, community artworks, and cultural artifacts.

64BE8F796104481586DE10B1640334F4.description: The structure of a narrative in visual arts can be represented using motifs, metaphors, and themes.

0726361121C94EC7AA6501710A2C91C7.description: A narrative in art can be depicted in two- and three-dimensional works, as seen in Basawan and Chetar Munti, Akbar's Adventure with the Elephant Hawa'i, c. 1561 Helen Granger Young, The Famous Five Monument, c. 2010

E8345E7233844C8795986B75E17B8A50.description: Pictures can be grouped in sets (diptych or triptych) as seen in Andrew Salgado, 20 Years, 2014 Robert Campin, The Merode Altarpiece, c. 1427-432

4658E7BF61104D72B0FAEBEFC6E5B952.description: A variety of media can be used to illustrate the order of events in a narrative, including storyboards, paintings, and fabric arts.

0EE4D042E2814C5FAE7EE7EE919FA038.description: A narrative in visual arts may or may not represent a sequence of events in the order in which they happened

97ADBA5F7A834930AADEA93420B01351.description: Inspiration for a narrative may come from stories music various forms of media real people or characters experiences imagination the environmen

9C9E0324B9AF4B00994A2473DCCBBE2B.description: Students employ narrative as a structure for organizing ideas in artworks

D0080DC4185D4774B6762C78DB440FCB.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge

A5E8DC13AA5F4876B0816BBAF43DF898.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to discuss how texture exists in threedimensional works of art.

DC6F7B108BB84739BE0740B52934E1BC.description: Use various materials to create texture in artworks

39A645A9EC144F4BB7E40CC1AE308AE4.description: Describe how the use of texture can elicit a response from a viewer.

3153D67070CD48F7982222BDDD9C7330.description: Explore how texture can be used to create a visual effect.

78FE1C4568E94C6FBE8DE77922459BA0.description: Investigate where natural pigments come from and how they were used in the past.

5DE7CC7A07564CB39A3C89E7E3B2C026.description: Experiment with how to create neutral colours by mixing complementary colours

9CBFA31218174126A3B827FEA45A2360.description: Express preferences related to the use of colour in artworks

8C843DCB3EAC4016A2C848D2A8FFE6AC.description: Assess the use of colour in artworks to represent feelings and create mood

7B7497729C254273BF9C28816C72C51C.description: Explore the effect in using warm and cool colours in artworks.

53FC0B041A8F4BCDAA07B8C1DF582504.description: Explore how colour can create harmony or contrast in artworks

1A9A45B873A9499FAD0B498FE4AC5BBD.description: Describe how the use of warm and cool colours contributes to a composition

EC29F62458D642E59FC14B3BCB42D91B.description: Examine how the illusion of mass or volume can be created by adjusting value.

FFB73BA7701447EAABB268AAB65F4DC8.description: Investigate how colour and value can create contrast in artworks

368899496B0A40509DBE74367A1294D0.description: Experiment with how to apply monochromatic colour to artworks.

4AB5300FA749449D86141F4C6CF28CCB.description: Observe and discuss how artists employ value in a variety of artworks.

4995F9A4140C4C0B994188E91E4C91E4.description: Explore how to create tints, shades, and gradation.

5B54D6532A2E4517BAE0EEC62B4AF4BD.description: Texture can enhance the visual impact of artworks.

B7884F4F53F940BEA3B25A69EEEA9971.description: Texture can create a visual effect that is realistic and creates mood in artworks

D3178B55A9C045BCB35FFDCCFDFFF67A.description: Colour is determined by the pigments in an object or a material

93C4B255FF7946B6B06EF66C2D64BDC5.description: Colour can impact the viewer's response to an artwork

2C5C449C4C9A43DB8B1CF2069FE39094.description: Value indicates the lightness or darkness of a colour

61FF1D5762934FCEB0412D15C654C44D.description: Colour has the physical property of value.

038086499B8B4C339236ED38793A13BD.description: Texture contributed to historical architecture, as seen in Alhambra Palace, Spain Dome of the Rock, Mosque of Omar, Jerusalem Taj Mahal, India

4AEF72CE8E1C4334B9366804871D7DEB.description: Texture can create an effect in artworks, as seen in Christi Belcourt, Nathalie, 2014 Faith Ringgold, Woman on a Bridge #1 of 5: Tar Beach, c. 1988

6E5AD64C405F4FA9B7FBF916676816FA.description: Fabric art is created by using materials that have texture, including fibres or yarn thread and needle to create stitching tie-dye batik or resist dyeing

45D6222F55C1430488513675B68787B7.description: Collage is a kind of artwork created by using a variety of materials that can vary in texture, including paper photographs fabric yarn plastics

1B0BA12369ED4471B5AEF33C7A8B5075.description: Several textures can be applied to create contrast for effect.

D7E83BFA13404DCDA1E1C70742B8B919.description: Texture can be applied to artworks in a subtle or an exaggerated way.

32E7C33394354E259A9F18071E7B354C.description: Texture can be inviting, by eliciting a positive response such as curiosity, or less inviting, by provoking a negative response such as disgust.

CB731CCA338D45E8B981C977F6FFFC99.description: The colour quality or pigment may vary within different media

227F14395F0B4E45BD96D88B401A60C9.description: Pigments are added to paints to give them colour

AA31B7217E0E403EB1CC69C248F3B335.description: Pigments are coloured materials that are typically insoluble in water, unless ground into a fine powder first

7396919851EB4540AA2E3ABCA832700D.description: Natural pigments come from the land and can be found in plants, animals, and minerals, including clay hematite, an ore of iron in the colours black, silver, grey, brown, or red charcoal

32E286ED06A64D24B5077E88493FC4EA.description: Pigments used in artworks today are typically manufactured

6805D03FEB9446AD8DF21DF28FB41117.description: Two complementary colours will create a neutral colour when mixed.

BA99CF6952074F56B66785BB42EEB2D9.description: Colours can be interpreted to complement another colour, including the colour pairs yellow-violet, red-green, blue-orange

554CEA494B6240029A9A9E4240D9B79C.description: Combining colours can create a sense of harmony or contrast in artworks, as seen in Tom Thomson, The Jack Pine, 1916-1917

5108AE5CD4674CEBB696D473F570CF48.description: Harmony is a principle of design that can be achieved by combining colours that are pleasing to the eye

A544894A2D4847828687F974D5582C7A.description: Examples of cool colours can be seen in Alex Colville, To Prince Edward Island, 1965 Katsushika Hokusai, The Great Wave off Kanagawa, c. 1829-1832

104C55037CD74A359A1B89795852683A.description: Examples of warm colours can be seen in Ted Harrison, Flying South, 1993 Vincent van Gogh, Sunflowers, c. 1888

1B6980DDE056489A90B826421AD31B71.description: Warm and cool colours in an artwork can have an emotional effect for a viewer

87CBDEFAC602499188D9C918E3539238.description: Colour can be described as having temperature that is warm, which includes red, orange, and yellow cool, which includes blue, green, and violet

8CDB829E77D74BFC9FC5DC956BCE3DF4.description: Colour can express or represent feelings and create mood

ACDE4996A3254D17BB6124A76ADD11F6.description:
A monochromatic colour originates
from a single hue and can be
developed using shades and tints,
as seen in
Gustav Klimt, Portrait of Adele
Bloch-Bauer I, 1907
Hendrick van Anthonissen,
Shipping in a Gale, c. 1656

087DB91CD9684A0B81F4950324836AF7.description: When colours with different values or hues are placed next to each other in a composition, the illusion of an edge, a shape, or a line can emerge

EB203199E97A4C0196AAB594E3B34A5F.description: Value can give the illusion of mass or volume in two-dimensional works of art

12F871497E724C6DBB7435959F41896F.description: Adjusting the value of a colour can provide contrast in artworks

86D45A95825345F6927353EE16FDCC4D.description: The value of a colour can increase or decrease in lightness or darkness, known as gradation

EFA896A1C853455BB7723363D3B5D401.description: Neutral colours include black, grey, white, and brown

75512D317C324D8BB260D044A05C5443.description: When black is added to a colour it becomes a shade

835AAD583DE3465ABE6D241F524884CB.description: When white is added to a colour it becomes a tint.

DDF382BB0279474D99A30AB851F72620.description: Colour can be lightened or darkened by creating tints and shades

73A8B84880894334BDF06AD5F32F3F58.description: Students evaluate how texture can contribute to detail within a composition.

AD266D6A6C3F4056A329F9D2B1B90CFB.description: Students interpret the role of colour in artworks.

68BFD187CF4D465A809DCE77EE5E9513.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
